text: I never felt that my racer Jenner was an
obstacle I thought it was an advantage
but sometimes people would ask me well
how do you feel having an artist for a
daughter and I said it's like I'm
running this relay race you know and I
had the baton and then I see her out of
the corner of my eye she's coming up
she's catching me and I handed to her
and she takes off and it's a great
feeling
people people also say well what's your
family business art is our family
business yeah I don't feel either of us
are really part of the big art piercing
mm-hmm kind of Lunars for me because I'm
a child of the depression I was always
like a junkie kid finding stuff and
going to flea markets and and thrift
stores you find something and you make
something out of it you can make art out
of anything you can find stuff and you
can go in your studio and paint it so I
wouldn't have to do anything and it was
a freedom to that the joy of being an
artist is just to find the objects and
to put it together and that's what makes
me happy it's like I told Martha Tucker
she was at the Whitney Museum at that
time well I'd say you know if you show
me
you get three points not only am i a
woman but I'm a woman of color and an
older woman and then later on she gave
me an exhibition at the Whitney Museum
which was my first museum show
doesn't seem to you that it was really
the New York galleries and museums that
were embracing artists african-american
artists before Los Angeles was yes
artists who really felt they had to make
it would go to New York I never felt
that way ever somebody's happy that's
right here they that way I felt
that way and but I think also in some
ways those doors had been opened for my
generation by your generation growing up
to me it seemed very evident that there
were basically two separate art worlds
it's interesting for me to hear you say
now that that wasn't an issue because I
know for a lot of those artists it was
that well we were invisible to to
museums and to the gallery scene we were
just invisible
but you know that didn't really matter
to what kind of art I made and I should
only make the art that I felt
comfortable in making and that was
important to me and that's kind of
always been my path
